Answer: The US is the most technologically advanced nation there ever was, so obviously not! I had the privilege of living there for 4 years in the 90s. It was a little like a sci-fi movie when someone gets transported to the future - I would just wander about gazing at the technological marvels that surrounded me. Just to pick out some of the highlights:1) Domestic life - I was once visiting a friend’s house and their mother happened to be loading clothes into the washing machine. She turned to me and said, “Do you have washing machines in Scotland?” Obviously, I was forced to admit, that no we didn’The US is the most technologically advanced nation there ever was, so obviously not! I had the privilege of living there for 4 years in the 90s. It was a little like a sci-fi movie when someone gets transported to the future - I would just wander about gazing at the technological marvels that surrounded me. Just to pick out some of the highlights:1) Domestic life - I was once visiting a friend’s house and their mother happened to be loading clothes into the washing machine. She turned to me and said, “Do you have washing machines in Scotland?” Obviously, I was forced to admit, that no we didn’t. Instead we just went down to the river and bashed our clothes off rocks to clean them.2) Transport - I spent two weeks in the lovely town of Columbia. Missouri. There I amazed the locals with my insistence on using a strange outmoded form of transport known as “walking”. Locals would slow down as they passed in their modern cars, pointing and laughing. To them, it must have been like watching a live action version of the Flintstones.3) Voting – would you believe it, but in the UK we still vote by drawing a little X next to the candidate we want to vote for. No sign of the advanced electronic voting they have over in the states. Indeed, we are so old fashioned that we haven’t even outsourced our voting to the Russians yet!4) Guns – It may be hard for an American to believe but almost nobody in the UK owns their own guns. This means that if we have to rise up and overthrow our own government (currently seems like a good plan) then we will be armed with nothing more than some particularly well sharpened sarcasm.Still, perhaps one day we can hope to be as advanced as the US. And there is some hope, as we now have our very own version of Donald Trump as PM!4K

Answer: I guess your question actually means “where would we be without fossil fuels?”Well, the steam engine was crucial for the first industrial revolution, and that means coal. However, a lot has been accomplished with wind and water power before that, but slowly, and biomass can be used to fire steam engine boilers, too.Without fossil fuels, huge tall ships would have dominated the oceans, and wood-fired rail would provide ground transportation. Perhaps there would be cars fueled by alcohol, biogas and generator gas, and similarly powered airships, but no airplanes. Of course, these would be much lI guess your question actually means “where would we be without fossil fuels?”Well, the steam engine was crucial for the first industrial revolution, and that means coal. However, a lot has been accomplished with wind and water power before that, but slowly, and biomass can be used to fire steam engine boilers, too.Without fossil fuels, huge tall ships would have dominated the oceans, and wood-fired rail would provide ground transportation. Perhaps there would be cars fueled by alcohol, biogas and generator gas, and similarly powered airships, but no airplanes. Of course, these would be much less efficient than our present transportation technology, so the economy would be far less globalized.However, the impetus to harness the power of first wind and water, and then solar and nuclear power (once the physics advances sufficiently) would be much stronger. Technological development would be slower at first, but once we reached 1950s level of scientific knowledge, it would explode.In the long term, we would probably be better off. But we are going in that direction anyway — the brief age of fossil fuels is behind us.

You need two things, lift, and thrust. If you put a VERY LARGE engine under the building (assuming you have disconnected it from its foundation) to counter the pull of gravity. Answer: We are nowhere near it.Nowhere. Not even slightly.An exoskeleton that allows the user to have greater strength for lifting in specific circumstances? Yes. But not a suit. A suit that allows you to breathe? Sure, with GIANT tanks attached to it, for a couple hours.Let’s break down what the suit is and why we can’t have nice things… yet. (and I’m not even going to use the new nano particle suit, just the one from Iron Man I - the very first movie, the basic suit).Fully enclosed suit:We are nowhere near it.Nowhere. Not even slightly.An exoskeleton that allows the user to have greater strength for lifting in specific circumstances? Yes. But not a suit. A suit that allows you to breathe? Sure, with GIANT tanks attached to it, for a couple hours.Let’s break down what the suit is and why we can’t have nice things… yet. (and I’m not even going to use the new nano particle suit, just the one from Iron Man I - the very first movie, the basic suit).Fully enclosed suit:Self contained:Tiny Power Source:Inertia Dampening:Recycling:Strength actuators:Mind Interface:The suit is slow, and easily overcome by attackers if you manipulate it any other way thanRepulsorsAIExotic materials:Actual Holographic displays:As you see any ONE of these inventions would revolutionize its industry and change our lives for the better, but you need ALL of them to replicate his suit. You need the actuators to give it the stretch but the suit would fall apart from stress so you need the exotic materials but then you need to power it so you need a power source that generates enough power in a tiny space that doesn’t kill the wearer with radiation and heat, but you can’t fly unless you have repulsors and then you can’t control it because you don’t have the mind interface, but then you are limited in what you can do unless you have the most advanced and complete and benign AI installed but you can’t do that unless you have the computing power that is insanely powerful in a tiny space and none of that matters because a couple hits from physical attacks would turn your body and brain to jelly from the outside shocks so you need electronic inertial dampeners that would put the Enterprise to shame.And that’s why we can’t have nice things.PS - I’m sure I missed something. :)

Answer: Suppose you had an adversarial friend in high school who bragged about how he was going to be the world's best mountain climber. Naturally you wanted to outdo him, so you started researching all about mountaineering and started climbing a few small mountains nearby. One thing leads to another and you both become pretty good mountain climbers while still in your twenties.Finally you make a bold plan to summit Mount Everest before your friend does. So you gather up some funding and shell out $50,000 for travel, permits, insurance, guide fees and of course, lots of expensive equipment. All your hSuppose you had an adversarial friend in high school who bragged about how he was going to be the world's best mountain climber. Naturally you wanted to outdo him, so you started researching all about mountaineering and started climbing a few small mountains nearby. One thing leads to another and you both become pretty good mountain climbers while still in your twenties.Finally you make a bold plan to summit Mount Everest before your friend does. So you gather up some funding and shell out $50,000 for travel, permits, insurance, guide fees and of course, lots of expensive equipment. All your hard work and finances finally pays off and you make it to the top of Everest by the age of 30. Seeing the inevitable writing on the wall, your friend (Soviet Union) loses interest.And just to prove it wasn't a fluke you return a few more times in the next several years. Your plan is to keep climbing year after year, with various improvements, but Congress (your new wife) has other plans. She feels that since you've "been there, done that" it's not really necessary to continue the missions because she would rather appropriate funds for a new house and a new car.Now you should understand why we haven't sent subsequent missions to the Moon after Apollo 17.Image:
name: Francisco Muñoz
question: https://www.quora.com/Were-the-Sans-or-Khoi-Khois-more-advanced-technologically-pre-modern-times

Answer: Q: If the moon landing really did take place more than 40 years back, how come we haven't done it more often by now?Because is was really, really, really expensive, and because we’ve had no compelling practical reason to return.In a way, the Apollo program was all the greater because it had little practical value. Sure, fear of the USSR and saber rattling got the ball rolling, but fundamentally, we went to the moon becauseQ: If the moon landing really did take place more than 40 years back, how come we haven't done it more often by now?Because is was really, really, really expensive, and because we’ve had no compelling practical reason to return.In a way, the Apollo program was all the greater because it had little practical value. Sure, fear of the USSR and saber rattling got the ball rolling, but fundamentally, we went to the moon becauseBut also, the Apollo program sort of shot itself in the foot. By publicly committing the nation to a landing by the end of the decade, President Kennedy set in motion a political monster that gobbled up resources at an alarming rate. Development had to start while basic research was still going on. Engines had to be chosen before spacecraft designs were in hand. Critical systems had not just built-in redundancy, but whole redundant systems using different technologies in case the primary didn’t work out. And instead of designing reusable vehicles and assembling missions from multiple launches of smaller, more manageable boosters, we built the biggest baddest rocket the world has ever seen—and made it disposable.It took half a million people and the combined military and industrial resources of the wealthiest nation on Earth to put the first boot prints on the moon. And while we were getting there, the Space Nuclear Propulsion Office, in concert with Los Alamos and the Marshall Space Flight Center, developed an atomic rocket engine called NERVA and started talking it up as the power plant for manned exploration of Mars.It would have been awesome, but congress wasn’t about to pay for it. They strangled NERVA, canceled Apollo, and gave NASA far more humble objectives to last the next generation.It’s a mixed bag. The impetus of the moon shot is still felt today in ways that most people aren’t aware of—not in the invention of the Space Pen or Velcro (neither of which were developed by NASA) but in the shape and capability of our industry and institutions of research and learning. Apollo helped send Voyager to Saturn, Sojorner to Mars, and Elon Musk into the space ferry business.And now here we are. Many of the cutting edge military-grade technologies that went into Apollo are now standard aerospace tech. Many of the technologies and fabrication techniques developed for Apollo are antiquated and out of date. And now, private industry is talking about sending mankind back to the moon and beyond.No one can say whether we’d be farther ahead or farther behind without Apollo. But I can say this: We did a great, bold, noble, and honorable thing, and we did it exceptionally well. That’s something worth honoring in this age of anti-intellectualism and anti-government rhetoric.

Answer: If man did indeed walk on the moon in the 1960s, why don't we repeat the feat today even though we have far more resources today, much more superior technology and massively improved computing power at our disposal?I’m probably going to regret wading into this, but damn it, I never seem to learn.Anyhow, here goes.PROLOG: There’s no “if” to consider. Yeah, yeah, I know — it was impossible/it was a hoax/the equipment couldn’t have worked/<insert favorite idea>. Well, these have all been debunked. Repeatedly. Comprehensively.[1]Now, let’s look at the superior technologies that we really do have.If man did indeed walk on the moon in the 1960s, why don't we repeat the feat today even though we have far more resources today, much more superior technology and massively improved computing power at our disposal?I’m probably going to regret wading into this, but damn it, I never seem to learn.Anyhow, here goes.PROLOG: There’s no “if” to consider. Yeah, yeah, I know — it was impossible/it was a hoax/the equipment couldn’t have worked/<insert favorite idea>. Well, these have all been debunked. Repeatedly. Comprehensively.[1]Now, let’s look at the superior technologies that we really do have. Here’s the thing: they don’t really help all with the problem all that much.Computing isn’t a big deal. I can do the necessary calculations on a $10 microcontroller card. I can add really fancy graphics if I use a $40 card named for a dessert dish. Space-rated computing hardware is expensive because it has to be built with traceable, high reliability components. A lot of times, they have to use radiation-hardened components. After building it all, it has to be tested to exacting standards. Such things are hideously expensive.Modern materials technologies would help, and we would shed mass from all kinds of parts. Unfortunately, we wouldn’t dare use some of the newest materials. It’s the same problem as before: everything built for space has to be well-tested, well-understood and reliable. Many really great materials just aren’t going to be suitable for space applications.Where there could be a really big bonus in materials is in the pressure suits and lunar EVA suits. We could make them lighter, tougher, and less uncomfortable. We probably couldn’t increase individual EVA times, as the astronauts were pretty exhausted at the end of the long EVAs. Perhaps we could have a few more EVAs.Power generation technologies have improved, so we could probably provide more compact and reliable batteries, fuel cells, and solar arrays. That certainly helps, but what it means is that the safety margins could be improved from “this is really, crazy dangerous” to “this is pretty dangerous.”Rocket technologies have improved quite a bit, but it’s not as big a factor as you’d think. Cryogenic fuels are still difficult to store and handle in space. Hypergolic fuels are still the same combinations we used 50 years ago. The only real difference is that we’d have to add a lot more equipment for safety requirements. We were really too cavalier about those fuels back then. Again, we’ve become more safety conscious, so what we’d probably achieve is better safety margins more than big capability improvements.Finally, space flight is extremely expensive. When you put humans into that equation, it becomes more expensive and yet still dangerous. No government has thought it worth the effort, the expense, and the political capital to repeat human spaceflight to the Moon.You can argue about the merits of that decision — argue endlessly, I imagine. That doesn’t change the reality, though. We went to the Moon. Then we got tired of it. That’s pretty much it in a nutshell.[1] To the the folks who want to say I’m wrong/nuts/deluded/a shill/<insert assessment>, don’t bother. I’ve heard it all. I’ve had people yell at me, and even spit at me while they yelled. Here’s the only reply I’ll make to such comments: use Quora’s search system, or Google, or whatever you like, and read the answers I’ve already posted. While you’re at it, check out the dozens of excellent answers from other folks here. I’m not going over it again.
name: David Johnson

Answer: Trivial? Look into the cost of putting a kilogram of material into Low Earth Orbit and then find out how that cost changes the further out you go and then you can start throwing “trivial” around.Computer power isTrivial? Look into the cost of putting a kilogram of material into Low Earth Orbit and then find out how that cost changes the further out you go and then you can start throwing “trivial” around.Computer power isNow, if back in the 60s the US government had decided to go to the moon to stay, not just as a PR stunt, you could rightly expect progress on rocket technology because people’s lives would depend on it. But NASA took the goal set by President Kennedy - to reach the moon by the end of the decade - very, very,So NASA designed Apollo to be a disposable system. Start with a big-a$$ rocket and throw all the parts away as you use them until you are left with a bare tin can full of astronauts and rocks returning by parachute and nothing left in the gas tank, not fumes, not even the tank. When you design a transportation system that literally consumes itself as it works, you are left with no infrastructure to build on.

Answer: Several reasons (none of them exactly perfect) conspire to make it difficult to send humans back to the moon:Several reasons (none of them exactly perfect) conspire to make it difficult to send humans back to the moon:That said - there are some new options:For me, the moon just isn’t very interesting - we need fancier robotic and orbital missions do better science - and if humans are to be sent anywhere, it should be Mars.There are two things we need to know for the future of all humanity:Mankind deserves the answers to those two questions - and that’s why we need a manned mission to Mars…but the Moon doesn’t help us answer those things, so (IMHO) it’s a waste of money to send people there again.

Answer: You betcha. It would be tons easier to return to the Moon than it was to get there in the 1960s. Therefore…there is a lesson for all of our fellow nerds:Life is about more than technology.Life is, in part, about expressing the will to do the things that technology lets us do. Had we applied that will to our elected representatives in the USA, we could have returned to the Moon a long time ago, had truly high-speed trains in the 1990s, switched primarily to renewable energy resources years ago, introduced Big Data techniques to harvest the data of millions of people to determine what causes manYou betcha. It would be tons easier to return to the Moon than it was to get there in the 1960s. Therefore…there is a lesson for all of our fellow nerds:Life is about more than technology.Life is, in part, about expressing the will to do the things that technology lets us do. Had we applied that will to our elected representatives in the USA, we could have returned to the Moon a long time ago, had truly high-speed trains in the 1990s, switched primarily to renewable energy resources years ago, introduced Big Data techniques to harvest the data of millions of people to determine what causes many presently obscure diseases and what cures them. And much, much, more.The fact that one person, Elon Musk, is involved in doing many of the things I mention is less a matter of his brilliance—though he is quite smart—and more a proof of how little it takes to actually make progress. He has access to a large amount of concentrated capital, but there are plenty of ways to allow groups of people to pool their resources just as effectively. So, let’s go back to the Moon. And to Mars. And to the bottom of the ocean and every other place that tickles our curiosity. If we’ve elected people who aren’t behind what we want, let’s get some who are.

Answer: We DID land on the moonSome specialised observatories regularly illuminate corner reflectors that astronauts left on the moon. These shine laser beams and view the reflected signal in telescopes. With the reflected signal the distance of the Moon can be tracked to a few millimetres. They can’t pretend they’re there, they need them to get results.Also, they went to the moon 9 times. Why go so many times if they’re not really going? It makes no sense, you’d just do it once and lie about that. Less people involved, less evidence to hide, less lies to cover up.If we didn’t go, why is it still a sWe DID land on the moonSome specialised observatories regularly illuminate corner reflectors that astronauts left on the moon. These shine laser beams and view the reflected signal in telescopes. With the reflected signal the distance of the Moon can be tracked to a few millimetres. They can’t pretend they’re there, they need them to get results.Also, they went to the moon 9 times. Why go so many times if they’re not really going? It makes no sense, you’d just do it once and lie about that. Less people involved, less evidence to hide, less lies to cover up.If we didn’t go, why is it still a secret?The American government has released plenty of secret information about experiments on the general public and assassination attempts in other countries. Why would this one pointless thing remain secret? The amount of money required to hide it this long, would out way the funds they gained at the time. Hiding it just wouldn’t be worth the effort involved.The only reason we don’t go there, is there’s no point. The moon is a barren landscape, with no easily accessible resources. We’ve got all the samples we need, there are no experiments we can’t replicate on the ISS (international space station).Actually, I’m guessing the amount of money, time and effort required to deny the moon landings, could, if all added together, actually finance another moon landing.Brings up a good point. Almost all the moon landing deniers have expertise in space travel. Why not spend their time productively working out ways to make it cheaper and safer. Make it cheap and safe enough, we might even get investors for holiday trips to the moon :)

Answer: There are many reasons, mainly the facts that:so in the 60s obviously the us government pumped a lot of money into nasa to fund landing on the moon. They didn't do this for science or to help humanity reach for the stars and explore, they did it because Russia had beaten them to stable orbit, beaten them to the first man to Eva in space etc andThere are many reasons, mainly the facts that:so in the 60s obviously the us government pumped a lot of money into nasa to fund landing on the moon. They didn't do this for science or to help humanity reach for the stars and explore, they did it because Russia had beaten them to stable orbit, beaten them to the first man to Eva in space etc and could not allow them to be the first to land a man on the moon. Now when America proved it had the largest manhood in this area, naturally the government saw little more reason to fund nasa and so cut their funding by a lot.The saturn rockets cost an insane amount of money to build and they are a 1 use throw away object that cannot be re-used. Elon musk actually found that most of the cost was down to the fact that nasa contracted out the building of most of the parts for the rockets they use so they are built y the likes of Lockheed Martin etc and they charge a lot more money than it actually costs. This is why space x (one of two companies nasa uses to launch its supply missions to the iss) invested money into learning how to build their own rockets thus cutting costs.space x also found that the technology used to build rockets until very recently hasn't actually changed an awful lot since the 60s, an no effort was made to beat the main cost which is the fact that the vehicle is a one use only thing. This is why space x have been working so hard to design rocket boosts than can land themselves after they detach from the space craft to be used on later flights, something they have succeeded in and I'm not sure on exact numbers but space x actually now he more advanced rockets than nasa that are built way way more cheaply because they are 1) built totally in house 2) use more modern technology and 3) are starting to become more re-usable.so they reasons we havnt been back aren't because humanity is stupid it's because nasa does not have the funds to launch manned missions to the moon anymore using current technology, there is no will for the powers that hold the money to return thus until nasa and space x advance a little bit more toward building cheaper reusable rockets that will bring the cost down to a manageable amount, I don't think we will mare frequent return missions for a while.
